Title: Arte - The_Namer's Review - MyAnimeList.net
Data: MyAnimeList.net      Hide AdsLoginSign Up  AllAnimeMangaCharactersPeopleCompaniesManga StoreNewsFeatured ArticlesForumClubsUsers               View all results for ${ keyword }  Anime  Anime Search Top Anime Seasonal Anime Videos Reviews Recommendations 2022 ChallengeFantasy Anime League  Manga  Manga Search Top Manga Manga Store Reviews Recommendations 2022 Challenge   Community  Interest Stacks Forums Clubs Blogs Users   Industry  News Featured Articles People Characters Companies MAL√óJapan   Watch  Episode Videos Anime Trailers  Read  Manga Store   Help  About Support Advertising FAQ Report StaffMAL Supporter     Reviews                Top                           ¬† > ¬†               Anime                           ¬† > ¬†               Arte                           ¬† > ¬†               Reviews                           ¬† > ¬†               The_Namer's Review                               Apr 9, 2022                    12 of 12 episodes seen                 Overall Rating:         8          Arte  (Anime) add            (All reviews)                         The_Namer (All reviews)   1                people found this review helpful                           more pics      Overall 8   Story 8   Animation 6   Sound 6   Character 7   Enjoyment 8                              Yet another show that has been misattributed as Slice of Life on MAL. At this point I'm convinced that label gets slapped on any anime that doesn't revolve around fight scenes. Be in no doubt though, while Arte's tale of a young noble girl who runs away from home to become an artist doesn't involve overt fisticuffs, the story has more in common with sports anime like Hajime no Ippo than it does with SoL shows like Yurucamp. The trademark SoL genre traits of minimal conflict and loose plot structure are nowhere to be found here.  Set in renaissance Florence, Arte's quest to become a professional artist is met with constant roadblocks due to the overwhelming sexism of the time. Armed with borderline genki girl tenacity, Arte bull rushes her way through each obstacle, often becoming literally bruised and bloodied in the process. This results in a classic battle anime fight-then-bond cycle where Arte's unwavering drive and spirit turns today's opponents into tomorrow's friends. The first episode even follows the classic sports anime trope of the grumpy master setting the cocky young whelp a seemingly impossible test because he thinks she's underestimated the hard work and guts required.  If the show does have one problem, it's in setting the bar too low for itself at times. By setting the story in a time and place even more sexist than modern Japan, we end up with a cast of characters who spend the first several episodes being baffled that a girl would attempt to do anything other than bat her eyelashes at potential suitors, which can get repetitive. While this does present strong conflicts for Arte to overcome, the story can come across as being a little too pleased with itself for having her accomplish... well, basically anything. It's not too much of a blemish on an otherwise engaging story, however, especially when this is one where the protagonist views even falling in love as just another obstacle getting in the way of her career. Title: Akebi-chan no Sailor-fuku - cat_coffee's Review - MyAnimeList.net
Data: MyAnimeList.net      Hide AdsLoginSign Up  AllAnimeMangaCharactersPeopleCompaniesManga StoreNewsFeatured ArticlesForumClubsUsers               View all results for ${ keyword }  Anime  Anime Search Top Anime Seasonal Anime Videos Reviews Recommendations 2022 ChallengeFantasy Anime League  Manga  Manga Search Top Manga Manga Store Reviews Recommendations 2022 Challenge   Community  Interest Stacks Forums Clubs Blogs Users   Industry  News Featured Articles People Characters Companies MAL√óJapan   Watch  Episode Videos Anime Trailers  Read  Manga Store   Help  About Support Advertising FAQ Report StaffMAL Supporter     Reviews                Top                           ¬† > ¬†               Anime                           ¬† > ¬†               Akebi-chan no Sailor-fuku                           ¬† > ¬†               Reviews                           ¬† > ¬†               cat_coffee's Review                               Apr 9, 2022                    12 of 12 episodes seen                 Overall Rating:         10          Akebi-chan no Sailor-fuku  (Anime) add            (All reviews)                         cat_coffee (All reviews)   1                people found this review helpful                           more pics      Overall 10   Story 10   Animation 10   Sound 10   Character 10   Enjoyment 10                              Akebi's Sailor Uniform is a great dream while it lasts. And then I realized it's a dream I'll never get back.   Akebi is a Mary Sue because that's what a teenage girl would write in her fantasy. You'll see a lot of girls with their own problems. Too short, too tall, too inexperienced, too fat, a projection of all the worries a middle-school girl would have. All one-note characters, but after learning notes, you proceed to understand chords. It's girl of the week until everything is tied together.  Hebimori's episode does a great job on the music. You will be wondering why a piano is playing instead of guitar music. It's interesting because the story goes from using Akebi as a lens to explore the school to needing Akebi to keep everything together.   The fanservice is certainly artistic but I think of it as something to live with. As we grow into adults, we learn to restrain ourselves. Yet as a middle-schooler, Akebi and friends don't quite have that sense of self-control. Thus, the show focuses on "socially-acceptable" things to stare at like armpits and feet and turns it up to eleven.  Animation is great, art is great, the OP starts off strong and energetic. The ED is tragically fuzzy and nostalgic and the father can barely take any time off to see his family. I don't think I've cried to an anime as much as this one.              Helpful       report

Title: Kenja no Deshi wo Nanoru Kenja - NeisanAnimeList's Review - MyAnimeList.net
Data: MyAnimeList.net      Hide AdsLoginSign Up  AllAnimeMangaCharactersPeopleCompaniesManga StoreNewsFeatured ArticlesForumClubsUsers               View all results for ${ keyword }  Anime  Anime Search Top Anime Seasonal Anime Videos Reviews Recommendations 2022 ChallengeFantasy Anime League  Manga  Manga Search Top Manga Manga Store Reviews Recommendations 2022 Challenge   Community  Interest Stacks Forums Clubs Blogs Users   Industry  News Featured Articles People Characters Companies MAL√óJapan   Watch  Episode Videos Anime Trailers  Read  Manga Store   Help  About Support Advertising FAQ Report StaffMAL Supporter     Reviews                Top                           ¬† > ¬†               Anime                           ¬† > ¬†               Kenja no Deshi wo Nanoru Kenja                           ¬† > ¬†               Reviews                           ¬† > ¬†               NeisanAnimeList's Review                               Apr 9, 2022                    12 of 12 episodes seen                 Overall Rating:         6          Kenja no Deshi wo Nanoru Kenja  (Anime) add            (All reviews)                         NeisanAnimeList (All reviews)   0                people found this review helpful                           more pics      Overall 6   Story 7   Animation 7   Sound 5   Character 7   Enjoyment 6                              TLDR: The plot on paper is good the execution is shoddy. Still enjoyable to me as I am easy to please but don't expect any uber attention grabbing moments. Lacks seriousness, but very light-hearted if that's what you like.  I think the whole premise of the story is interesting and intriguing on paper. You suddenly wake up in the video game you love not knowing when or why it happened, yet 30 years have passed and another friend of yours who plays was waiting for you the whole time. On top of which the other 7 players that you used to play with are missing which you have to find is another interesting storyline as well.   These two separate storylines could be cohesive as finding more players not just the seven could lead to info about what happened and how everyone started living and breathing the game in a literal sense came about, but the episodes severely lack this. Even episodes that seem to pertain to the main plot points lack anything substantial in progressing the story.  Overall, it is an anime that seems like the plot is really good and may have some interesting dark or serious moments but the anime's execution is very lighthearted and feels empty. As though, I was watching filler episodes.              Helpful       report

Data: Top                           ¬† > ¬†               Anime                           ¬† > ¬†               Kenja no Deshi wo Nanoru Kenja                           ¬† > ¬†               Reviews                           ¬† > ¬†               NeisanAnimeList's Review                               Apr 9, 2022                    12 of 12 episodes seen                 Overall Rating:         6          Kenja no Deshi wo Nanoru Kenja  (Anime) add            (All reviews)                         NeisanAnimeList (All reviews)   0                people found this review helpful                           more pics      Overall 6   Story 7   Animation 7   Sound 5   Character 7   Enjoyment 6                              TLDR: The plot on paper is good the execution is shoddy. Still enjoyable to me as I am easy to please but don't expect any uber attention grabbing moments. Lacks seriousness, but very light-hearted if that's what you like.  I think the whole premise of the story is interesting and intriguing on paper. You suddenly wake up in the video game you love not knowing when or why it happened, yet 30 years have passed and another friend of yours who plays was waiting for you the whole time. On top of which the other 7 players that you used to play with are missing which you have to find is another interesting storyline as well.   These two separate storylines could be cohesive as finding more players not just the seven could lead to info about what happened and how everyone started living and breathing the game in a literal sense came about, but the episodes severely lack this. Even episodes that seem to pertain to the main plot points lack anything substantial in progressing the story.  Overall, it is an anime that seems like the plot is really good and may have some interesting dark or serious moments but the anime's execution is very lighthearted and feels empty. As though, I was watching filler episodes.              Helpful       report

Title: Beginner's Guide to Jujutsu Kaisen! | Featured News | Tokyo Otaku Mode (TOM) Shop: Figures & Merch From Japan
Data: Tokyo Otaku ModeShopNewsGalleryOtapediaLog InSign UpFEATUREDANIMEMANGAMOVIEEVENTFIGUREARTCOSPLAYJAPANHOW TOFASHIONPRODUCTGAMEMUSICPRESS RELEASEBeginner's Guide to Jujutsu Kaisen!FEATUREDMar. 4, 2021 09:20High school student Yuji Itadori is just a regular kid, if you don‚Äôt count his amazing strength, supernatural speed, the fact that he ate a cursed finger‚Ä¶ Alright, scratch that. Of course he‚Äôs nowhere near normal ‚Äì he‚Äôs the hero of  Jujutsu Kaisen (Âë™Ë°ìÂªªÊà¶, Jujutsu Kaisen), a dark fantasy manga by Gege Akutami (Ëä•Ë¶ã‰∏ã„ÄÖ, Akutami Gege) with a 24-episode anime series by MAPPA. Set in a world where sorcerers must fight deadly curses born of negative emotions,  Jujutsu Kaisen combines its dark premise with a refreshing modern setting, relatable characters and of course, plenty of action. Read on to learn more about the world of  Jujutsu Kaisen, along with its characters, keywords and more! Contents1. Story2. Setting3. Characters- 3.1¬†Jujutsu High students- 3.2 Jujutsu High faculty- 3.3 Antagonists4. Keywords5. Main media- 5.1 Manga- 5.2 TV anime series- 5.3 Anime film StoryDespite being blessed with extraordinary athleticism, fifteen-year-old Yuji Itadori refuses to have anything to do with his high school‚Äôs track team. His choice? The Occult Research Club. However, his world is thrown into chaos when a cursed talisman in the form of a rotting finger is unsealed at school. To protect his friends, Yuji swallows the finger, which is actually a fragment of legendary "King of Curses" Ryomen Sukuna, and becomes possessed himself. Although this effectively signs his death warrant, the intervention of powerful sorcerer Satoru Gojo sets him on a different path: to consume the rest of Sukuna‚Äôs fingers so he can destroy the curse ‚Äì and himself ‚Äì forever.  SettingTo be human is to experience not only positive feelings, but also negative emotions like sadness, regret and shame. In  Jujutsu Kaisen, such emotions produce cursed energy, which transforms into curses that can bring misfortune to the world. While normal humans cannot control this, Jujutsu Sorcerers are able to harness their own cursed energy to use certain techniques. With their supernatural powers, these sorcerers secretly protect humans from curses and the threats they pose to society. Characters ‚Äì¬†Jujutsu High studentsYuji Itadori (ËôéÊùñ ÊÇ†‰ªÅ, Itadori Y≈´ji)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA fifteen-year-old with extraordinary athleticism. Good-natured and always willing to help those around him, Yuji particularly values the importance of life and having a ‚Äúfair death‚Äù, which was instilled in him by his dead grandfather. As a result, he eats Sukuna‚Äôs finger to save his friends and thus becomes the present-day vessel of the ‚ÄúKing of Curses.‚Äù He then enrolls in Jujutsu High to become a sorcerer himself under the tutelage of Satoru Gojo. Through lessons and missions, he learns more about cursed energy and how to control it, boosting his already impressive physical abilities. He is voiced by Junya Enoki (Japanese) and Adam McArthur (English). Megumi Fushiguro (‰ºèÈªíÊÅµ, Fushiguro Megumi)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA first-year student. Megumi‚Äôs search for a cursed object leads him to meet Yuji and witness his self-sacrifice first-hand, despite them being strangers. Secretive and calculating, he nevertheless believes in helping those who are good and kind, as seen when he vouches for Yuji in the face of the latter‚Äôs impending execution. The two are later reunited as fellow students under the tutelage of Satoru Gojo. Megumi‚Äôs sorcery talents include summoning Shikigami (spirits) for offense and exorcisms. He is voiced by Yuma Uchida (Japanese) and Robbie Daymond (English).Nobara Kugisaki (ÈáòÂ¥éÈáéËñîËñá, Kugisaki Nobara)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA first-year student hailing from the country. As one of Satoru‚Äôs students, she teams up with Yuji and Megumi for various missions. Self-confident and quick to speak her mind, she takes pride in her own identity, abilities and appearance. Nobara‚Äôs distinctive battle style includes the use of hammers and nails infused with cursed energy.  She is voiced by Asami Seto (Japanese) and Anne Yatco (English).Maki Zen'in (Á¶™Èô¢ÁúüÂ∏å, Zen'in Maki)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA second-year student who participates in the event with their sister school in Kyoto. Despite being born to a clan of elite Jujutsu Sorcerers, Maki doesn't have the ability to control cursed energy or even see curses. However, she compensates for this with amazing physical strength and talent with all sorts of cursed tools. She is voiced by Mikako Komatsu (Japanese) and Allegra Clark (English).Toge Inumaki (ÁãóÂ∑ªÊ£ò, Inumaki Toge)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA second-year student who participates in the sister school event. His power is channeled through cursed speech ‚Äì words imbued with his cursed energy. To ensure that his abilities don't affect people in everyday situations, he only uses words that can be fillings for rice balls. He is voiced by Koki Uchiyama (Japanese) and Xander Mobus (English).Panda („Éë„É≥„ÉÄ, Panda)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA second-year student who participates in the sister school event with Maki and Toge. Despite his appearance as a full-sized panda, he can speak like a human and is also an exceptionally powerful sorcerer. He is voiced by Tomokazu Seki (Japanese) and Matthew David Rudd (English). ‚Äì¬†Jujutsu High facultySatoru Gojo (‰∫îÊù°ÊÇü, Goj≈ç Satoru)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA powerful sorcerer and teacher who mentors Yuji, Megumi and Nobara. After Yuji is sentenced to death for being possessed by Sukuna, Satoru proposes that they wait until all of the fingers are consumed, which would give them the chance to destroy Sukuna once and for all. He is renowned for his immense power and battle prowess to the point that his self-proclamation of being the world‚Äôs strongest Jujutsu Sorcerer goes unchallenged. He is voiced by Yuichi Nakamura (Japanese) and Kaiji Tang (English).Masamichi Yaga (Â§úËõæÊ≠£ÈÅì, Yaga Masamichi)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteJujutsu High's principal and a passionate educator who once mentored Gojo. He has the ability to bring dolls to life and control them through his cursed corpse technique. He is voiced by Takaya Kuroda (Japanese) and Keith Silverstein (English). ‚Äì¬†AntagonistsRyomen Sukuna (‰∏°Èù¢ÂÆøÂÑ∫, Ry≈çmen Sukuna)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA legendary curse inhabiting Yuji‚Äôs body. Also translated as "Double Faced Specter." Known as the "King of Curses", Sukuna resisted all exorcism attempts, driving sorcerers of centuries ago to cut off and hide his 20 fingers in order to seal his power. His character has roots in Japanese legend, with references to a two-faced, 8-armed and 8-legged man with supernatural strength in Nihon Shoki, the second oldest book of Japanese history. He is voiced by Junichi Suwabe (Japanese), and Ray Chase (English).Suguru Geto (Â§èÊ≤π ÂÇë, Get≈ç Suguru)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA Special Grade Jujutsu Sorcerer who wishes to transform the world into a "paradise" that would house sorcerers only. He is voiced by Takahiro Sakurai (Japanese) and Lex Lang (English).Jogo (ÊºèÁëö, J≈çgo)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA powerful curse born of fear of the earth. He believes that his own kind is humanity's true form because cursed spirits originate from pure emotion, as opposed to humans and their false emotions. He is voiced by Shigeru Chiba (Japanese) and Michael Sorich (English).Hanami (Ëä±Âæ°, Hanami)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA powerful curse born of fear of the forests. They wish to eliminate humans so they stop hurting the environment. They are voiced by Atsuko Tanaka. Keywords ‚Äì¬†Curses (Âë™„ÅÑ, noroi) / Cursed Spirits (Âë™Èúä, jurei) Spiritual beings given form by cursed energy (see below). Particularly likely to manifest in places like hospitals and schools, they are the cause of countless mysterious deaths and disappearances in general society, with regular people unable to see them. However, Jujutsu Sorcerers are able to see, fight and exorcise them. Curses vary greatly in appearance and power, and are ranked by strength with Grades 1-4 (4 being the weakest) and Special Grade (the very strongest). They may also be sealed in artifacts as Sukuna was, becoming cursed objects (Âë™Áâ©, jubutsu) that can still emit cursed energy.  ‚Äì¬†Cursed Energy (Âë™Âäõ, juryoku)A form of energy that arises from humans‚Äô negative emotions, like hate, regret, and shame, and gives form to curses. While regular people are unable to control it, Jujutsu Sorcerers (see below) and curses are able to harness their own cursed energy for combat.  ‚Äì¬†Jujutsu Sorcerer (Âë™Ë°ìÂ∏´, jujutsu-shi)Individuals who have been trained to combat curses using Jujutsu spells and techniques at one of Japan‚Äôs two recognized Jujutsu educational institutions. They are tasked with various missions, the difficulty of which should match their grade as a sorcerer, with Grade 4 being the lowest and Special Grade being the highest. These duties may involve exorcising curses, investigating curse-related incidents, and so on.  ‚Äì¬†Tokyo Prefectural Jujutsu High School (Êù±‰∫¨ÈÉΩÁ´ãÂë™Ë°ìÈ´òÁ≠âÂ∞ÇÈñÄÂ≠¶Ê†°, T≈çkyo Toritsu Jujutsu Senmon Gakk≈ç)A 4-year institution where aspiring Jujutsu Sorcerers gather to train their craft. It can also be translated as Tokyo Metropolitan Magic Technical School and abbreviated as Jujutsu High. One of Japan‚Äôs only two Jujutsu schools, it is located in the suburbs of Tokyo, with the other (its sister school) located in Kyoto. However, it is disguised as a religious school and is further hidden and protected from outside threats by a protective barrier. It is common for fully-fledged sorcerers to come back to Jujutsu High to teach students, as well as manage and support missions. Main media MangaSource: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteWritten and illustrated by Gege Akutami,  Jujutsu Kaisen first began serialization in  Weekly Shonen Jump in March 2018. Before this, however, a 4-chapter series titled Tokyo Metropolitan Curse Technical School ran in Jump GIGA. Featuring a different main character named Yuta, it was published as a single volume titled  Jujutsu Kaisen 0. Still ongoing with 15 volumes as of March 2021, the main series is one of the best-selling manga series of all time. Over 30 million copies are in circulation (including digital releases) as of February 2021. English translations are currently available online through Shueisha‚Äôs Manga Plus app and website. It's also been released in print for North America through Viz Media. Get a peek at the manga here! TV Anime SeriesThe MAPPA-produced anime series debuted in Japan on October 3, 2020 and is slated to run for 24 episodes over two seasons. Directed by Sunghoo Park and written by Hiroshi Seko, it covers the manga's story up to roughly Volume 7. For countries outside of Asia,  Jujutsu Kaisen is available to stream through Crunchyroll. Check out the first episode below!As well as dynamic animation, there are also four theme songs to enjoy: "Kaikai Kitan" by Eve (first opening theme), "Lost in Paradise feat. AKLO" by ALI (first ending theme), "Vivid Vice" by Who-ya Extended (second opening theme), and "Give it Back" by C√∂ Shu Nie (second ending theme). Get started with "Kaikai Kitan" below! Anime FilmMAPPA is producing an anime film titled  Gekijoban Jujutsu Kaisen 0 ( Jujutsu Kaisen 0: The Movie ). Set for release in winter 2021, the film's story will be based on Tokyo Metropolitan Curse Technical School, the 4-chapter prequel series that was also published in a volume as  Jujutsu Kaisen 0.Source: Jujutsu Kaisen film's official websiteFeel like a bigger taste of  Jujutsu Kaisen? Sit down, maybe get yourself a (hopefully non-finger shaped) snack, and head on your first mission with Yuji! Before this, however, a 4-chapter series titled Tokyo Metropolitan Curse Technical School ran in Jump GIGA. Featuring a different main character named Yuta, it was published as a single volume titled  Jujutsu Kaisen 0. Still ongoing with 15 volumes as of March 2021, the main series is one of the best-selling manga series of all time. Over 30 million copies are in circulation (including digital releases) as of February 2021. English translations are currently available online through Shueisha‚Äôs Manga Plus app and website. It's also been released in print for North America through Viz Media. Get a peek at the manga here! TV Anime SeriesThe MAPPA-produced anime series debuted in Japan on October 3, 2020 and is slated to run for 24 episodes over two seasons. Directed by Sunghoo Park and written by Hiroshi Seko, it covers the manga's story up to roughly Volume 7. For countries outside of Asia,  Jujutsu Kaisen is available to stream through Crunchyroll. Check out the first episode below!As well as dynamic animation, there are also four theme songs to enjoy: "Kaikai Kitan" by Eve (first opening theme), "Lost in Paradise feat. AKLO" by ALI (first ending theme), "Vivid Vice" by Who-ya Extended (second opening theme), and "Give it Back" by C√∂ Shu Nie (second ending theme). Get started with "Kaikai Kitan" below! Anime FilmMAPPA is producing an anime film titled  Gekijoban Jujutsu Kaisen 0 ( Jujutsu Kaisen 0: The Movie ). Set for release in winter 2021, the film's story will be based on Tokyo Metropolitan Curse Technical School, the 4-chapter prequel series that was also published in a volume as  Jujutsu Kaisen 0.Source: Jujutsu Kaisen film's official websiteFeel like a bigger taste of  Jujutsu Kaisen? Sit down, maybe get yourself a (hopefully non-finger shaped) snack, and head on your first mission with Yuji! Title: Beginner's Guide to Jujutsu Kaisen! | Featured News | Tokyo Otaku Mode (TOM) Shop: Figures & Merch From Japan
Data: Beginner's Guide to Jujutsu Kaisen!FEATUREDMar. 4, 2021 09:20High school student Yuji Itadori is just a regular kid, if you don‚Äôt count his amazing strength, supernatural speed, the fact that he ate a cursed finger‚Ä¶ Alright, scratch that. Of course he‚Äôs nowhere near normal ‚Äì he‚Äôs the hero of  Jujutsu Kaisen (Âë™Ë°ìÂªªÊà¶, Jujutsu Kaisen), a dark fantasy manga by Gege Akutami (Ëä•Ë¶ã‰∏ã„ÄÖ, Akutami Gege) with a 24-episode anime series by MAPPA. Set in a world where sorcerers must fight deadly curses born of negative emotions,  Jujutsu Kaisen combines its dark premise with a refreshing modern setting, relatable characters and of course, plenty of action. Read on to learn more about the world of  Jujutsu Kaisen, along with its characters, keywords and more! Contents1. Story2. Setting3. Characters- 3.1¬†Jujutsu High students- 3.2 Jujutsu High faculty- 3.3 Antagonists4. Keywords5. Main media- 5.1 Manga- 5.2 TV anime series- 5.3 Anime film StoryDespite being blessed with extraordinary athleticism, fifteen-year-old Yuji Itadori refuses to have anything to do with his high school‚Äôs track team. His choice? The Occult Research Club. However, his world is thrown into chaos when a cursed talisman in the form of a rotting finger is unsealed at school. To protect his friends, Yuji swallows the finger, which is actually a fragment of legendary "King of Curses" Ryomen Sukuna, and becomes possessed himself. Although this effectively signs his death warrant, the intervention of powerful sorcerer Satoru Gojo sets him on a different path: to consume the rest of Sukuna‚Äôs fingers so he can destroy the curse ‚Äì and himself ‚Äì forever.  SettingTo be human is to experience not only positive feelings, but also negative emotions like sadness, regret and shame. In  Jujutsu Kaisen, such emotions produce cursed energy, which transforms into curses that can bring misfortune to the world. While normal humans cannot control this, Jujutsu Sorcerers are able to harness their own cursed energy to use certain techniques. With their supernatural powers, these sorcerers secretly protect humans from curses and the threats they pose to society. Characters ‚Äì¬†Jujutsu High studentsYuji Itadori (ËôéÊùñ ÊÇ†‰ªÅ, Itadori Y≈´ji)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA fifteen-year-old with extraordinary athleticism. Good-natured and always willing to help those around him, Yuji particularly values the importance of life and having a ‚Äúfair death‚Äù, which was instilled in him by his dead grandfather. As a result, he eats Sukuna‚Äôs finger to save his friends and thus becomes the present-day vessel of the ‚ÄúKing of Curses.‚Äù He then enrolls in Jujutsu High to become a sorcerer himself under the tutelage of Satoru Gojo. Through lessons and missions, he learns more about cursed energy and how to control it, boosting his already impressive physical abilities. He is voiced by Junya Enoki (Japanese) and Adam McArthur (English). Megumi Fushiguro (‰ºèÈªíÊÅµ, Fushiguro Megumi)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA first-year student. Megumi‚Äôs search for a cursed object leads him to meet Yuji and witness his self-sacrifice first-hand, despite them being strangers. Secretive and calculating, he nevertheless believes in helping those who are good and kind, as seen when he vouches for Yuji in the face of the latter‚Äôs impending execution. The two are later reunited as fellow students under the tutelage of Satoru Gojo. Megumi‚Äôs sorcery talents include summoning Shikigami (spirits) for offense and exorcisms. He is voiced by Yuma Uchida (Japanese) and Robbie Daymond (English).Nobara Kugisaki (ÈáòÂ¥éÈáéËñîËñá, Kugisaki Nobara)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA first-year student hailing from the country. As one of Satoru‚Äôs students, she teams up with Yuji and Megumi for various missions. Self-confident and quick to speak her mind, she takes pride in her own identity, abilities and appearance. Nobara‚Äôs distinctive battle style includes the use of hammers and nails infused with cursed energy.  She is voiced by Asami Seto (Japanese) and Anne Yatco (English).Maki Zen'in (Á¶™Èô¢ÁúüÂ∏å, Zen'in Maki)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA second-year student who participates in the event with their sister school in Kyoto. Despite being born to a clan of elite Jujutsu Sorcerers, Maki doesn't have the ability to control cursed energy or even see curses. However, she compensates for this with amazing physical strength and talent with all sorts of cursed tools. She is voiced by Mikako Komatsu (Japanese) and Allegra Clark (English).Toge Inumaki (ÁãóÂ∑ªÊ£ò, Inumaki Toge)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA second-year student who participates in the sister school event. His power is channeled through cursed speech ‚Äì words imbued with his cursed energy. To ensure that his abilities don't affect people in everyday situations, he only uses words that can be fillings for rice balls. He is voiced by Koki Uchiyama (Japanese) and Xander Mobus (English).Panda („Éë„É≥„ÉÄ, Panda)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA second-year student who participates in the sister school event with Maki and Toge. Despite his appearance as a full-sized panda, he can speak like a human and is also an exceptionally powerful sorcerer. He is voiced by Tomokazu Seki (Japanese) and Matthew David Rudd (English). ‚Äì¬†Jujutsu High facultySatoru Gojo (‰∫îÊù°ÊÇü, Goj≈ç Satoru)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA powerful sorcerer and teacher who mentors Yuji, Megumi and Nobara. After Yuji is sentenced to death for being possessed by Sukuna, Satoru proposes that they wait until all of the fingers are consumed, which would give them the chance to destroy Sukuna once and for all. He is renowned for his immense power and battle prowess to the point that his self-proclamation of being the world‚Äôs strongest Jujutsu Sorcerer goes unchallenged. He is voiced by Yuichi Nakamura (Japanese) and Kaiji Tang (English).Masamichi Yaga (Â§úËõæÊ≠£ÈÅì, Yaga Masamichi)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteJujutsu High's principal and a passionate educator who once mentored Gojo. He has the ability to bring dolls to life and control them through his cursed corpse technique. He is voiced by Takaya Kuroda (Japanese) and Keith Silverstein (English). ‚Äì¬†AntagonistsRyomen Sukuna (‰∏°Èù¢ÂÆøÂÑ∫, Ry≈çmen Sukuna)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA legendary curse inhabiting Yuji‚Äôs body. Also translated as "Double Faced Specter." Known as the "King of Curses", Sukuna resisted all exorcism attempts, driving sorcerers of centuries ago to cut off and hide his 20 fingers in order to seal his power. His character has roots in Japanese legend, with references to a two-faced, 8-armed and 8-legged man with supernatural strength in Nihon Shoki, the second oldest book of Japanese history. He is voiced by Junichi Suwabe (Japanese), and Ray Chase (English).Suguru Geto (Â§èÊ≤π ÂÇë, Get≈ç Suguru)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA Special Grade Jujutsu Sorcerer who wishes to transform the world into a "paradise" that would house sorcerers only. He is voiced by Takahiro Sakurai (Japanese) and Lex Lang (English).Jogo (ÊºèÁëö, J≈çgo)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA powerful curse born of fear of the earth. He believes that his own kind is humanity's true form because cursed spirits originate from pure emotion, as opposed to humans and their false emotions. He is voiced by Shigeru Chiba (Japanese) and Michael Sorich (English).Hanami (Ëä±Âæ°, Hanami)Source: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteA powerful curse born of fear of the forests. They wish to eliminate humans so they stop hurting the environment. They are voiced by Atsuko Tanaka. Keywords ‚Äì¬†Curses (Âë™„ÅÑ, noroi) / Cursed Spirits (Âë™Èúä, jurei) Spiritual beings given form by cursed energy (see below). Particularly likely to manifest in places like hospitals and schools, they are the cause of countless mysterious deaths and disappearances in general society, with regular people unable to see them. However, Jujutsu Sorcerers are able to see, fight and exorcise them. Curses vary greatly in appearance and power, and are ranked by strength with Grades 1-4 (4 being the weakest) and Special Grade (the very strongest). They may also be sealed in artifacts as Sukuna was, becoming cursed objects (Âë™Áâ©, jubutsu) that can still emit cursed energy.  ‚Äì¬†Cursed Energy (Âë™Âäõ, juryoku)A form of energy that arises from humans‚Äô negative emotions, like hate, regret, and shame, and gives form to curses. While regular people are unable to control it, Jujutsu Sorcerers (see below) and curses are able to harness their own cursed energy for combat.  ‚Äì¬†Jujutsu Sorcerer (Âë™Ë°ìÂ∏´, jujutsu-shi)Individuals who have been trained to combat curses using Jujutsu spells and techniques at one of Japan‚Äôs two recognized Jujutsu educational institutions. They are tasked with various missions, the difficulty of which should match their grade as a sorcerer, with Grade 4 being the lowest and Special Grade being the highest. These duties may involve exorcising curses, investigating curse-related incidents, and so on.  ‚Äì¬†Tokyo Prefectural Jujutsu High School (Êù±‰∫¨ÈÉΩÁ´ãÂë™Ë°ìÈ´òÁ≠âÂ∞ÇÈñÄÂ≠¶Ê†°, T≈çkyo Toritsu Jujutsu Senmon Gakk≈ç)A 4-year institution where aspiring Jujutsu Sorcerers gather to train their craft. It can also be translated as Tokyo Metropolitan Magic Technical School and abbreviated as Jujutsu High. One of Japan‚Äôs only two Jujutsu schools, it is located in the suburbs of Tokyo, with the other (its sister school) located in Kyoto. However, it is disguised as a religious school and is further hidden and protected from outside threats by a protective barrier. It is common for fully-fledged sorcerers to come back to Jujutsu High to teach students, as well as manage and support missions. Main media MangaSource: Jujutsu Kaisen official websiteWritten and illustrated by Gege Akutami,  Jujutsu Kaisen first began serialization in  Weekly Shonen Jump in March 2018. Before this, however, a 4-chapter series titled Tokyo Metropolitan Curse Technical School ran in Jump GIGA. Featuring a different main character named Yuta, it was published as a single volume titled  Jujutsu Kaisen 0. Still ongoing with 15 volumes as of March 2021, the main series is one of the best-selling manga series of all time. Over 30 million copies are in circulation (including digital releases) as of February 2021. English translations are currently available online through Shueisha‚Äôs Manga Plus app and website. It's also been released in print for North America through Viz Media. Get a peek at the manga here! TV Anime SeriesThe MAPPA-produced anime series debuted in Japan on October 3, 2020 and is slated to run for 24 episodes over two seasons. Directed by Sunghoo Park and written by Hiroshi Seko, it covers the manga's story up to roughly Volume 7. For countries outside of Asia,  Jujutsu Kaisen is available to stream through Crunchyroll. Check out the first episode below!As well as dynamic animation, there are also four theme songs to enjoy: "Kaikai Kitan" by Eve (first opening theme), "Lost in Paradise feat. AKLO" by ALI (first ending theme), "Vivid Vice" by Who-ya Extended (second opening theme), and "Give it Back" by C√∂ Shu Nie (second ending theme). Get started with "Kaikai Kitan" below! Anime FilmMAPPA is producing an anime film titled  Gekijoban Jujutsu Kaisen 0 ( Jujutsu Kaisen 0: The Movie ). Set for release in winter 2021, the film's story will be based on Tokyo Metropolitan Curse Technical School, the 4-chapter prequel series that was also published in a volume as  Jujutsu Kaisen 0.Source: Jujutsu Kaisen film's official websiteFeel like a bigger taste of  Jujutsu Kaisen? Set for release in winter 2021, the film's story will be based on Tokyo Metropolitan Curse Technical School, the 4-chapter prequel series that was also published in a volume as  Jujutsu Kaisen 0.Source: Jujutsu Kaisen film's official websiteFeel like a bigger taste of  Jujutsu Kaisen? Sit down, maybe get yourself a (hopefully non-finger shaped) snack, and head on your first mission with Yuji! This is a Tokyo Otaku Mode original article.

Title: Beginner's Guide to Jujutsu Kaisen! | Featured News | Tokyo Otaku Mode (TOM) Shop: Figures & Merch From Japan
Data: High school student Yuji Itadori is just a regular kid, if you don‚Äôt count his amazing strength, supernatural speed, the fact that he ate a cursed finger‚Ä¶ Alright, scratch that. Of course he‚Äôs nowhere near normal ‚Äì he‚Äôs the hero of  Jujutsu Kaisen (Âë™Ë°ìÂªªÊà¶, Jujutsu Kaisen), a dark fantasy manga by Gege Akutami (Ëä•Ë¶ã‰∏ã„ÄÖ, Akutami Gege) with a 24-episode anime series by MAPPA.

Title: Beginner's Guide to Jujutsu Kaisen! | Featured News | Tokyo Otaku Mode (TOM) Shop: Figures & Merch From Japan
Data: The MAPPA-produced anime series debuted in Japan on October 3, 2020 and is slated to run for 24 episodes over two seasons. Directed by Sunghoo Park and written by Hiroshi Seko, it covers the manga's story up to roughly Volume 7.

Title: Beginner's Guide to Jujutsu Kaisen! | Featured News | Tokyo Otaku Mode (TOM) Shop: Figures & Merch From Japan
Data: MAPPA is producing an anime film titled  Gekijoban Jujutsu Kaisen 0 ( Jujutsu Kaisen 0: The Movie ). Set for release in winter 2021, the film's story will be based on Tokyo Metropolitan Curse Technical School, the 4-chapter prequel series that was also published in a volume as  Jujutsu Kaisen 0.

Title: Date A Live IV Reveals Trailer Featuring Ending Theme! | Anime News | Tokyo Otaku Mode (TOM) Shop: Figures & Merch From Japan
Data: Tokyo Otaku ModeShopNewsGalleryOtapediaLog InSign UpFEATUREDANIMEMANGAMOVIEEVENTFIGUREARTCOSPLAYJAPANHOW TOFASHIONPRODUCTGAMEMUSICPRESS RELEASEDate A Live IV Reveals Trailer Featuring Ending Theme!ANIMEMar. 28, 2022 02:45Popular anime  Date A Live has released a new trailer that features the Season 4 ending theme, "S.O.S" by sweet ARMS!Based on the light novel series written by Tachibana Koushi and illustrated by Tsunako,  Date A Live follows high school boy Itsuka Shido, who proves unexpectedly irresistible to extraterrestrial spirits set on causing chaos on Earth.It was first adapted into a TV anime in 2013, with the second and third season airing in 2014 and 2019 respectively. The franchise also received an anime film in 2015. Date A Live IV (Season 4) will air from April 8, 2022.¬©2021 Koshi Tachibana, Tsunako/KADOKAWA/Date a Live IV Production CommitteeAdapted with permission from Anime!Anime!AnimeDate A LiveDate A Live IVDate A Live SeriesNewsundefinedThese are your people. Title: Shikimori's Not Just a Cutie Reveals Sweet Second Trailer! | Anime News | Tokyo Otaku Mode (TOM) Shop: Figures & Merch From Japan
Data: Tokyo Otaku ModeShopNewsGalleryOtapediaLog InSign UpFEATUREDANIMEMANGAMOVIEEVENTFIGUREARTCOSPLAYJAPANHOW TOFASHIONPRODUCTGAMEMUSICPRESS RELEASEShikimori's Not Just a Cutie Reveals Sweet Second Trailer!ANIMEMar. 28, 2022 03:55 Shikimori's Not Just a Cutie has released a second trailer for its April anime debut!The trailer also previews the anime's opening theme, "Honey Jet Coaster" by Nasuo‚òÜ. The ending theme is "Route BLUE" by Yuki Nakashima. Adapted from Keigo Maki's manga series,  Shikimori's Not Just a Cutie follows unlucky high school boy Izumi and his sweet girlfriend Shikimori, who transforms into an ultra cool lady whenever he gets into trouble.  Ryota Itoh (  My Senpai Is Annoying ) is directing at Doga Kobo with series composition by Yoshimi Narita ( Pretty Cure ), and character design by Ai Kikuchi (  New Game ). Shikimori's Not Just a Cutie will air in Japan from April 10, 2022.  ¬©Keigo Maki, Kodansha/Shikimori-san Production CommitteeAdapted with permission from Anime!Anime!AnimeNewsShikimori's Not Just a CutieundefinedMake new friends & get presents from TOM Senpai at the TOM Fan Club! Title: Teasing Master Takagi-san Film Unveils Trailer & Theme Song! | Anime News | Tokyo Otaku Mode (TOM) Shop: Figures & Merch From Japan
Data: Tokyo Otaku ModeShopNewsGalleryOtapediaLog InSign UpFEATUREDANIMEMANGAMOVIEEVENTFIGUREARTCOSPLAYJAPANHOW TOFASHIONPRODUCTGAMEMUSICPRESS RELEASETeasing Master Takagi-san Film Unveils New Trailer and Theme Song!ANIMEMar. 26, 2022 09:47Romcom anime  Teasing Master Takagi-san has revealed a new trailer for its first anime film!The trailer also features theme song "Hajimari no Natsu" by Yuiko Ohara, who performed the opening themes for Seasons 1 and 2, as well as the ending theme for Season 3.Adapted from Soichiro Yamamoto's manga series,  Teasing Master Takagi-san revolves around the daily life of a middle school girl named Takagi, who loves playing pranks on her classmate Nishikata while he tries to get revenge.The first season of the TV anime adaptation aired in 2018, with Season 2 following in 2019. Season 3 began airing in January 2022. The  Teasing Master Takagi-san anime film will open in Japan on June 10, 2022.¬©2022 Soichiro Yamamoto, Shogakukan/Teasing Master Takagi-san the Movie Production CommitteeAdapted with permission from Anime!Anime!AnimeNewsTeasing Master Takagi-sanundefinedThese are your people. Title: New Gundam Anime Unveils First Female Protagonist! | Anime News | Tokyo Otaku Mode (TOM) Shop: Figures & Merch From Japan
Data: Tokyo Otaku ModeShopNewsGalleryOtapediaLog InSign UpFEATUREDANIMEMANGAMOVIEEVENTFIGUREARTCOSPLAYJAPANHOW TOFASHIONPRODUCTGAMEMUSICPRESS RELEASEMobile Suit Gundam: The Witch From Mercury Unveils First Female Protagonist!ANIMEMar. 30, 2022 01:59Upcoming TV anime  Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch From Mercury has unveiled a teaser visual and video showcasing the heroine and her Gundam, Aerial! The Witch from Mercury is not only the first  Gundam TV anime in seven years, but also the first installment to feature a female protagonist. A prequel series titled  Prologue is also set to be produced. Scheduled to air this summer, it will feature the Gundams Lfrith and Beguir-Beu, who will be available as Gunpla model kits along with Gundam Aerial. Mobile Suit Gundam: The Witch From Mercury will air from October 2022. Title: TONIKAWA: Over the Moon for You New Episode to Air in Summer | Anime News | Tokyo Otaku Mode (TOM) Shop: Figures & Merch From Japan
Data: Tokyo Otaku ModeShopNewsGalleryOtapediaLog InSign UpFEATUREDANIMEMANGAMOVIEEVENTFIGUREARTCOSPLAYJAPANHOW TOFASHIONPRODUCTGAMEMUSICPRESS RELEASETONIKAWA: Over the Moon for You New Episode to Air This Summer!ANIMEApr. 5, 2022 11:45Source: Warner Bros. Japan Anime YouTube channelRomantic comedy anime  Tonikawa: Over The Moon For You will be back this summer with a special new episode! Titled Seifuku (Uniform), the episode was first announced in November 2021. It will also be available to stream via Crunchyroll from August 2022. Originally a manga series by Kenjiro Hata,  TONIKAWA: Over The Moon for You follows high school boy Nasa Yuzaki, who falls in love with a beautiful girl named Tsukasa after she saves him from a car accident. When he asks her out, she agrees on one condition: they have to get married first. The TV anime's first season aired from October to December 2019, with an OVA following in 2021. In addition to the new episode, a second season has been announced. Tonikawa: Over The Moon For You ~Seifuku~ will be released in summer 2022.¬© Kenjiro Hata, Shogakukan / Tonikawa CommitteeSource: Warner Bros. Japan Anime YouTube channelAnimeFly Me to the MoonNewsTonikaku KawaiiundefinedAll kinds of otaku are welcome at the TOM Fan Club! Title: ‚ÄúMACROSS PLUS MOVIE EDITION‚Äù Brings Pulse-Pounding Animated | Press Release News | Tokyo Otaku Mode (TOM) Shop: Figures & Merch From Japan
Data: Tokyo Otaku ModeShopNewsGalleryOtapediaLog InSign UpFEATUREDANIMEMANGAMOVIEEVENTFIGUREARTCOSPLAYJAPANHOW TOFASHIONPRODUCTGAMEMUSICPRESS RELEASE‚ÄúMACROSS PLUS MOVIE EDITION‚Äù Brings Pulse-Pounding Animated Mecha Combat to U.S. CinemasPRESS RELEASENov. 15, 2021 16:00 Fathom Events and BIGWEST Bring Cult Classic Anime to U.S. Screens for the First Time on December 14Denver - November 11, 2021 - Upon its initial release in 1994, ‚ÄúMACROSS PLUS‚Äù became a cult sensation paving the way for some of anime‚Äôs greatest hits and the creators behind them. The ground-breaking, 4-episode Original Video Animation (OVA) struck a chord with audiences worldwide with its blazingly fast dogfighting in detail that had never been seen in anime before. On December 14, ‚ÄúMACROSS‚Äù finally comes to U.S. cinemas with, ‚ÄúMACROSS PLUS MOVIE EDITION,‚Äù which adds all-new animated scenes never seen in the OVA, streamlines the storyline, and creates a more focused and action-packed viewing experience. In addition to the feature, attendees will view an exclusive special interview with creator/chief director Shoji Kawamori (‚ÄúMacross,‚Äù ‚ÄúAquarion,‚Äù ‚ÄúEscaflowne‚Äù).Tickets for ‚ÄúMACROSS PLUS MOVIE EDITION‚Äù can be purchased at www.FathomEvents.com or participating theater box offices. For a complete list of theater locations, visit the Fathom Events website (theater locations are subject to change).Combining the intricate designs of Shoji Kawamori, character direction from Shinichiro Watanabe (‚ÄúCowboy Bebop‚Äù), and the musical stylings of renown composer Yoko Kanno (‚ÄúCowboy Bebop,‚Äù ‚ÄúGhost in The Shell: SAC‚Äù), ‚ÄúMACROSS PLUS MOVIE EDITION‚Äù takes place in the year 2040 A.D., three decades after the glassing of Earth in what has since become known as Space War One. On the colonial planet of Eden, U.N. SPACY is testing transformable variable fighters to counter further alien attacks. Two prototype aircraft piloted by former childhood friends, loose cannon Isamu and the Zentradi mixed alien race Guld, go head-to-head in aerial and robot combat superiority over a lucrative military contract, and the affections of mutual love interest Myung. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre excited to partner with BIGWEST to finally bring ‚ÄòMACROSS PLUS MOVIE EDITION‚Äô to anime fans nationwide,‚Äù said Daren Miller, Fathom Events VP, Programming, Strategy & Business Affairs. ‚ÄúFor everyone that thinks ‚ÄòTop Gun‚Äô is exciting but would be better with Maverick and Iceman piloting robots, this one is for you.‚ÄùFor artwork/photos related to ‚ÄúMACROSS PLUS MOVIE EDITION‚Äù visit the Fathom Events press site. About Fathom EventsFathom is a recognized leader in the entertainment industry as one of the top distributors of content to movie theaters in North America. Owned by AMC Entertainment Inc. (NYSE: AMC); Cinemark Holdings, Inc. Title: ‚ÄúMACROSS PLUS MOVIE EDITION‚Äù Brings Pulse-Pounding Animated | Press Release News | Tokyo Otaku Mode (TOM) Shop: Figures & Merch From Japan
Data: Tokyo Otaku ModeShopNewsGalleryOtapediaLog InSign UpFEATUREDANIMEMANGAMOVIEEVENTFIGUREARTCOSPLAYJAPANHOW TOFASHIONPRODUCTGAMEMUSICPRESS RELEASE‚ÄúMACROSS PLUS MOVIE EDITION‚Äù Brings Pulse-Pounding Animated Mecha Combat to U.S. CinemasPRESS RELEASENov. 15, 2021 16:00 Fathom Events and BIGWEST Bring Cult Classic Anime to U.S. Screens for the First Time on December 14Denver - November 11, 2021 - Upon its initial release in 1994, ‚ÄúMACROSS PLUS‚Äù became a cult sensation paving the way for some of anime‚Äôs greatest hits and the creators behind them. The ground-breaking, 4-episode Original Video Animation (OVA) struck a chord with audiences worldwide with its blazingly fast dogfighting in detail that had never been seen in anime before. On December 14, ‚ÄúMACROSS‚Äù finally comes to U.S. cinemas with, ‚ÄúMACROSS PLUS MOVIE EDITION,‚Äù which adds all-new animated scenes never seen in the OVA, streamlines the storyline, and creates a more focused and action-packed viewing experience. In addition to the feature, attendees will view an exclusive special interview with creator/chief director Shoji Kawamori (‚ÄúMacross,‚Äù ‚ÄúAquarion,‚Äù ‚ÄúEscaflowne‚Äù).Tickets for ‚ÄúMACROSS PLUS MOVIE EDITION‚Äù can be purchased at www.FathomEvents.com or participating theater box offices. For a complete list of theater locations, visit the Fathom Events website (theater locations are subject to change).Combining the intricate designs of Shoji Kawamori, character direction from Shinichiro Watanabe (‚ÄúCowboy Bebop‚Äù), and the musical stylings of renown composer Yoko Kanno (‚ÄúCowboy Bebop,‚Äù ‚ÄúGhost in The Shell: SAC‚Äù), ‚ÄúMACROSS PLUS MOVIE EDITION‚Äù takes place in the year 2040 A.D., three decades after the glassing of Earth in what has since become known as Space War One. On the colonial planet of Eden, U.N. SPACY is testing transformable variable fighters to counter further alien attacks. Two prototype aircraft piloted by former childhood friends, loose cannon Isamu and the Zentradi mixed alien race Guld, go head-to-head in aerial and robot combat superiority over a lucrative military contract, and the affections of mutual love interest Myung. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre excited to partner with BIGWEST to finally bring ‚ÄòMACROSS PLUS MOVIE EDITION‚Äô to anime fans nationwide,‚Äù said Daren Miller, Fathom Events VP, Programming, Strategy & Business Affairs. ‚ÄúFor everyone that thinks ‚ÄòTop Gun‚Äô is exciting but would be better with Maverick and Iceman piloting robots, this one is for you.‚ÄùFor artwork/photos related to ‚ÄúMACROSS PLUS MOVIE EDITION‚Äù visit the Fathom Events press site. Title: 9 Reasons You Have to See Kimetsu no Yaiba: Mugen Train! | Featured News | Tokyo Otaku Mode (TOM) Shop: Figures & Merch From Japan
Data: Tokyo Otaku ModeShopNewsGalleryOtapediaLog InSign UpFEATUREDANIMEMANGAMOVIEEVENTFIGUREARTCOSPLAYJAPANHOW TOFASHIONPRODUCTGAMEMUSICPRESS RELEASEI Saw Kimetsu no Yaiba: Mugen Train 16 Times - Here Are 9 Reasons You Have to See It!FEATUREDJan. 30, 2021 02:00Note: The first section of this article does not include spoilers for  Demon Slayer -Kimetsu no Yaiba- The Movie: Mugen Train. A warning will be displayed before any spoilers are mentioned, so rest assured that you can read this article even if you haven‚Äôt watched it yet!Fantasy anime  Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba has taken not only Japan, but the entire world by storm. On October 16, 2020, a sequel,  Demon Slayer -Kimetsu no Yaiba- The Movie: Mugen Train, was released in Japan. In just 10 days, it earned over 100 billion yen in box office revenues, the fastest movie to have ever done so in Japan, and the two month mark saw it go past a whopping 300 million yen. If that wasn't enough, it even overtook  Studio Ghibli's  Spirited Away, previously the highest-grossing film in Japanese history - yet another record set at blazing speeds!Along with this wave of popularity, manga volumes and general  KnY merchandise has been selling out everywhere. Regardless of age and gender, the franchise has truly attracted passionate fans far and wide.Penned by a TOM Staff member and true  KnY fan who‚Äôs gone to see  Demon Slayer -Kimetsu no Yaiba- The Movie: Mugen Train an unbelievable 16 times, this article will introduce nine of its highlights - in other words, nine reasons to go and watch it when it's available where you are. Get ready to engage in some Total Concentration Reading!First, let‚Äôs talk about the background behind  Demon Slayer -Kimetsu no Yaiba- The Movie: Mugen Train. The original manga,  Demon Slayer: Kimetsu No Yaiba, tells the story of Tanjiro Kamado, a boy who embarks on a quest to heal his sister Nezuko, who has been transformed into a demon. During this journey, he and his companions must face intense battles against evil demons.  Mugen Train covers the 7th and 8th volumes of the manga. In terms of the TV anime series, the movie follows on from the story of the 26th and last episode, ‚ÄúNew Mission.‚Äù If you haven‚Äôt seen the TV anime yet, I recommend watching it first. For some quick information on the plot, setting, and key vocab, check out our guide to Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba!Now, watch closely‚Ä¶ and pay attention to these highlights! 1. Unbelievably Beautiful VisualsWhen it first came out, the TV anime's stunning animation and breathtaking battle scenes went viral. Of course, these high standards were maintained in the movie as well. Seeing those amazing battle scenes on the big screen was particularly overwhelming! The sheer speed made me feel like I was running through the screen with Tanjiro and the others, while the ominous figures of their enemies, the demons, had me shivering‚Ä¶ From the first scene of the advancing Mugen Train to the credits, you can dive right into the world of  KnY through the spectacular animation. And it‚Äôs not just the battle scenes ‚Äì charming country landscapes, the train‚Äôs striking interior, snowy mountains, the Rengoku family‚Äôs traditional Japanese house‚Ä¶ There‚Äôs just so much to enjoy in this amazing movie, produced by ufotable, a studio whose animation of katana and Japanese architechture has been well received in anime like  Touken Ranbu and much more. Be sure to look out for the backgrounds, too! Here‚Äôs a tip: each of the fusuma, or sliding doors, have especially elaborate designs.  2. The Flame Hashira: The One and Only Kyojuro RengokuOne thing I want ‚Äì or actually, need you to pay attention to is the second protagonist of Mugen Train: Kyojuro Rengoku, the Demon Slayer Corps‚Äô Flame Hashira. Many people may have been surprised at Kyojuro‚Äôs first appearance in the anime series ‚Äì the moment he lays eyes upon Nezuko, already a demon, and Tanjiro, who brought her, he orders that she be decapitated. This paints him as quite an unreasonable person who won‚Äôt even stop for an explanation first, but we go on to learn so much more about him. A son of the Rengoku family and its historic Fire Hashira lineage, we see his gentle soul, strength, and unwavering heart and convictions, as well as the loneliness that follows a man of his nature. All of this is sure to draw you to him as a character. At the beginning of Episode 24 of the anime series, Kyojuro is seen talking with Shinobu Kocho (the Insect Hashira) about his upcoming mission on the Mugen Train. He didn‚Äôt receive any battle scenes during the series, so the movie is the first time we actually get to see him and his Flame Breathing techniques in action. The flames that roar through the train, his unbelievably swift reactions, the movement of his cape, his intense red eyes that seem to see through all‚Ä¶Everything. Is. Way. Too. Cool.Seriously, everything about him is just so cool‚Ä¶ How am I meant to deal with this‚Ä¶ (I mean, I don‚Äôt have to.) The moment he began his Flame Breathing First Form: Shiranui, I realized, ‚ÄúOh, I‚Äôve pretty much spent nothing on this movie‚Ä¶ This is already worth the ticket‚Ä¶‚ÄùFrom his sword techniques to his mere presence and words, every part of Rengoku Kyojuro is priceless. Honestly, this movie leaves you no time to even blink. Everything is something to look out for. I don‚Äôt want you to let even a tenth of a second escape your attention, so be sure to use plenty of eye drops before it starts 3. The Mugen Train and its Real-Life OriginsLet‚Äôs take a look at a certain train otaku favorite in Japan, SL Hitoyoshi, which features an 8620 Class steam locomotive. Commonly known as ‚Äúhachiroku" (meaning "86‚Äù), it‚Äôs none other than the locomotive that inspired the appearance of the Mugen Train! From the beginning of the movie, we get plenty of glimpses at Japan in the Taisho Era (1912-1926), from the design of the station and passenger cars to the fashion of the passengers themselves. Through the animation, we also experience its sheer speed, as well as the actual sensation of being swayed as we ride in the heavy carriages. It‚Äôs downright awesome!Here in Japan, we actually got to see a collaboration between SL Hitoyoshi and  KnY, where the locomotive was transformed into a real-life Mugen Train for a limited run. Naturally, it was so popular that it was practically impossible to get your hands on tickets. (Yup, I didn‚Äôt manage to snag any either‚Ä¶) It quickly became a viral topic on social media, with people excited to see a ‚Äúreal-life Mugen Train‚Äù even in photos and videos.  4. Tanjiro‚Äôs Feelings For His FamilyKnY‚Äôs story begins with a powerful theme: family. We also see its importance in the movie, which beautifully illustrates Tanjiro‚Äôs feelings for his family. He‚Äôs already lost so many people important to him, but no matter how much he wants to return to those happy days, there‚Äôs no going back ‚Äì he'll never be able to see his loved ones again. This movie‚Äôs depiction of Tanjiro‚Äôs family, entangled in memories both happy and sad, but never to be restored, will have your eyes streaming with tears. 5. And Of Course, the Funny Scenes!Another great element that we get to see again are the hilarious moments between Inosuke and Zenitsu! You‚Äôll also find yourself chuckling at Rengoku as he scarfs down his ekiben (bento lunches bought at train stations). Another heads up ‚Äì at first Zenitsu‚Äôs dream sequence will probably just seem funny, but if you pay attention to where it‚Äôs set, that smile might turn into tears‚Ä¶ (This is especially aimed at anyone who‚Äôs already read the manga up to the Mugen Train arc ‚Äì I want you to think long and hard about where he is in that dream!) Spoiler Alert!From here, I‚Äôll be introducing specific details about the movie, so please stop reading if you want to avoid spoilers.‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚ÜìAlright! Let‚Äôs keep going with more highlights, including actual scenes from the movie! 6. An Unprecedented Battle of IntellectTanjiro‚Äôs new foe, and the demon controlling the Mugen Train is Enmu, Lower Rank One in the Twelve Kizuki. Before the events of the movie, Muzan himself took a liking to Enmu and gifted him with Muzan‚Äôs blood. Having gained power with this infusion, Enmu decides to enlist the help of humans ‚Äì or rather, use them as a means for his plan. Thus, the lives of Tanjiro, Zenitsu, Inosuke, Nezuko, and their mission companion, Rengoku, as well as the train‚Äôs many regular passengers, are Enmu‚Äôs next targets. His gentle and calm manner of speaking and friendly smile prove to make him an even more sinister character. Carrying out his plan with meticulous care, Enmu attempts to put Tanjiro and the other humans to sleep forever through his Blood Demon Art, a style of attack that they‚Äôve never faced before. How will Tanjiro and his fellow Demon Slayers wake themselves up from Enmu‚Äôs eternal dreams? 7. The Sudden Appearance of Upper Rank Three, AkazaThe last part of the movie takes a huge turn with the sudden appearance of Akaza (Upper Rank Three) and his fierce battle against Rengoku. Just before dawn, Tanjiro and the others finally get the chance to breathe a sigh of relief, having defeated Enmu and checked that the passengers are safe. But this only lasts for a moment, with the Demon Slayers gathered facing the dreaded Upper Rank Three for the first time. The sudden roaring sound signals the appearance of something... but then dies down, leaving an eerie silence. Then, a pair of eyes glisten in the darkness. This frightening sense of anticipation crosses the screen to weigh down on you, causing you to instinctively clench your fists in suspense‚Ä¶Despite Akaza being a favorite among  KnY‚Äôs many demons, we didn‚Äôt get any information on his voice actor, or even still images until the movie‚Äôs official release. As a result, fans speculated that the movie might only cover Enmu‚Äôs arc and stop before showing Akaza, or that the anime series would continue with his story. However, the movie‚Äôs premiere date came and the cat was finally let out of the bag. We now know that Akaza‚Äôs voice actor is Akira Ishida, famous for roles like Kaworu Nagisa in  Neon Genesis Evangelion! This casting was a huge yet welcome surprise for fans. If you‚Äôre watching the movie with Japanese audio, be sure to soak up every moment of Akaza‚Äôs malevolence, madness and despair through Ishida‚Äôs formidable voice acting!One more highlight is the overwhelming energy of Rengoku and Akaza in their battle scenes, yet another part where you can‚Äôt afford to blink. If IMAX screenings are available near you, take advantage of them and experience the fight‚Äôs sheer power at full volume. It goes without saying that you can still experience plenty at normal theaters, but I urge you to go and feel the huge impact behind each and every hit at IMAX volume levels! The depiction of the snowflake patterns in Akaza‚Äôs Technique Deployment ability is also a highlight. In the original manga‚Äôs 18th volume, we learn about Akaza‚Äôs past. Despite being a ruthless demon with numerous victims, the sorrows of his life as a human capture the pity of readers. Personally, he‚Äôs one of my favorite characters. After watching the movie, I also recommend going right to the rest of the manga to continue the story! 8. Tears of FrustrationAt the end of the battle, Tanjiro and his companions are overwhelmed by the realization that they are still too weak, no matter how much work they put in or how hard they train. Sneering down with their seemingly infinite power are the demons. Haunted by the thought that they couldn‚Äôt do anything, that they had to be protected by others, the young humans have faced frustration, sadness, and uncontrollable tears. For the sake of their slain family members and beloved people they still had to protect, they‚Äôve trained over and over, fought to survive the Final Selection, narrowly escaped death every night, and made huge progress. Yet their power was still nowhere near enough. And now, the man they had followed has fallen victim to their enemies. No matter how many times you watch the movie, this realization will tear your heart to shreds. In the face of such a tragedy, Inosuke offers some words that are deeply touching. His upbringing among wild boars may have given him less experience with other people, but we can see that he‚Äôs grown yet again as a human.  9. Rengoku‚Äôs Explosive Battle Through LifeFans who have already read the manga will know what I‚Äôm talking about. In any case, I won‚Äôt elaborate too much, but I urge you to burn his battles and his way of life into your mind ‚Äì why he risks his life in battle, why he tries to protect humans. His crystal-clear beliefs and promises will also give you an insight into the loneliness he must bear. Protect the weak. Respect one‚Äôs duty and values. In what light will you see these warriors and hear their words as they fight to protect others? If you have the chance, please find out on the big screen. Finally, let me leave you with these words: ‚ÄúKeep your heart burning!‚Äù (And don‚Äôt forget a handkerchief!)This is a Tokyo Otaku Mode original article with text and illustrations by HER.--Need some more quality time with the KnY crew? Bring them home with these adorable figures! Title: 9 Reasons You Have to See Kimetsu no Yaiba: Mugen Train! | Featured News | Tokyo Otaku Mode (TOM) Shop: Figures & Merch From Japan
Data: Tokyo Otaku ModeShopNewsGalleryOtapediaLog InSign UpFEATUREDANIMEMANGAMOVIEEVENTFIGUREARTCOSPLAYJAPANHOW TOFASHIONPRODUCTGAMEMUSICPRESS RELEASEI Saw Kimetsu no Yaiba: Mugen Train 16 Times - Here Are 9 Reasons You Have to See It!FEATUREDJan. 30, 2021 02:00Note: The first section of this article does not include spoilers for  Demon Slayer -Kimetsu no Yaiba- The Movie: Mugen Train. A warning will be displayed before any spoilers are mentioned, so rest assured that you can read this article even if you haven‚Äôt watched it yet!Fantasy anime  Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba has taken not only Japan, but the entire world by storm. On October 16, 2020, a sequel,  Demon Slayer -Kimetsu no Yaiba- The Movie: Mugen Train, was released in Japan. In just 10 days, it earned over 100 billion yen in box office revenues, the fastest movie to have ever done so in Japan, and the two month mark saw it go past a whopping 300 million yen. If that wasn't enough, it even overtook  Studio Ghibli's  Spirited Away, previously the highest-grossing film in Japanese history - yet another record set at blazing speeds!Along with this wave of popularity, manga volumes and general  KnY merchandise has been selling out everywhere. Regardless of age and gender, the franchise has truly attracted passionate fans far and wide.Penned by a TOM Staff member and true  KnY fan who‚Äôs gone to see  Demon Slayer -Kimetsu no Yaiba- The Movie: Mugen Train an unbelievable 16 times, this article will introduce nine of its highlights - in other words, nine reasons to go and watch it when it's available where you are. Get ready to engage in some Total Concentration Reading!First, let‚Äôs talk about the background behind  Demon Slayer -Kimetsu no Yaiba- The Movie: Mugen Train. The original manga,  Demon Slayer: Kimetsu No Yaiba, tells the story of Tanjiro Kamado, a boy who embarks on a quest to heal his sister Nezuko, who has been transformed into a demon. During this journey, he and his companions must face intense battles against evil demons.  Mugen Train covers the 7th and 8th volumes of the manga. In terms of the TV anime series, the movie follows on from the story of the 26th and last episode, ‚ÄúNew Mission.‚Äù If you haven‚Äôt seen the TV anime yet, I recommend watching it first. For some quick information on the plot, setting, and key vocab, check out our guide to Demon Slayer: Kimetsu no Yaiba!Now, watch closely‚Ä¶ and pay attention to these highlights! 1. Unbelievably Beautiful VisualsWhen it first came out, the TV anime's stunning animation and breathtaking battle scenes went viral. Of course, these high standards were maintained in the movie as well. Seeing those amazing battle scenes on the big screen was particularly overwhelming! The sheer speed made me feel like I was running through the screen with Tanjiro and the others, while the ominous figures of their enemies, the demons, had me shivering‚Ä¶ From the first scene of the advancing Mugen Train to the credits, you can dive right into the world of  KnY through the spectacular animation. And it‚Äôs not just the battle scenes ‚Äì charming country landscapes, the train‚Äôs striking interior, snowy mountains, the Rengoku family‚Äôs traditional Japanese house‚Ä¶ There‚Äôs just so much to enjoy in this amazing movie, produced by ufotable, a studio whose animation of katana and Japanese architechture has been well received in anime like  Touken Ranbu and much more. Be sure to look out for the backgrounds, too! Here‚Äôs a tip: each of the fusuma, or sliding doors, have especially elaborate designs.  2. The Flame Hashira: The One and Only Kyojuro RengokuOne thing I want ‚Äì or actually, need you to pay attention to is the second protagonist of Mugen Train: Kyojuro Rengoku, the Demon Slayer Corps‚Äô Flame Hashira. Many people may have been surprised at Kyojuro‚Äôs first appearance in the anime series ‚Äì the moment he lays eyes upon Nezuko, already a demon, and Tanjiro, who brought her, he orders that she be decapitated. This paints him as quite an unreasonable person who won‚Äôt even stop for an explanation first, but we go on to learn so much more about him. A son of the Rengoku family and its historic Fire Hashira lineage, we see his gentle soul, strength, and unwavering heart and convictions, as well as the loneliness that follows a man of his nature. All of this is sure to draw you to him as a character. At the beginning of Episode 24 of the anime series, Kyojuro is seen talking with Shinobu Kocho (the Insect Hashira) about his upcoming mission on the Mugen Train. He didn‚Äôt receive any battle scenes during the series, so the movie is the first time we actually get to see him and his Flame Breathing techniques in action. The flames that roar through the train, his unbelievably swift reactions, the movement of his cape, his intense red eyes that seem to see through all‚Ä¶Everything. Is. Way. Too. Cool.Seriously, everything about him is just so cool‚Ä¶ How am I meant to deal with this‚Ä¶ (I mean, I don‚Äôt have to.) The moment he began his Flame Breathing First Form: Shiranui, I realized, ‚ÄúOh, I‚Äôve pretty much spent nothing on this movie‚Ä¶ This is already worth the ticket‚Ä¶‚ÄùFrom his sword techniques to his mere presence and words, every part of Rengoku Kyojuro is priceless. Honestly, this movie leaves you no time to even blink. Everything is something to look out for. I don‚Äôt want you to let even a tenth of a second escape your attention, so be sure to use plenty of eye drops before it starts 3. The Mugen Train and its Real-Life OriginsLet‚Äôs take a look at a certain train otaku favorite in Japan, SL Hitoyoshi, which features an 8620 Class steam locomotive. Commonly known as ‚Äúhachiroku" (meaning "86‚Äù), it‚Äôs none other than the locomotive that inspired the appearance of the Mugen Train! From the beginning of the movie, we get plenty of glimpses at Japan in the Taisho Era (1912-1926), from the design of the station and passenger cars to the fashion of the passengers themselves. Through the animation, we also experience its sheer speed, as well as the actual sensation of being swayed as we ride in the heavy carriages. It‚Äôs downright awesome!Here in Japan, we actually got to see a collaboration between SL Hitoyoshi and  KnY, where the locomotive was transformed into a real-life Mugen Train for a limited run. Naturally, it was so popular that it was practically impossible to get your hands on tickets. (Yup, I didn‚Äôt manage to snag any either‚Ä¶) It quickly became a viral topic on social media, with people excited to see a ‚Äúreal-life Mugen Train‚Äù even in photos and videos.  4. Tanjiro‚Äôs Feelings For His FamilyKnY‚Äôs story begins with a powerful theme: family. We also see its importance in the movie, which beautifully illustrates Tanjiro‚Äôs feelings for his family. He‚Äôs already lost so many people important to him, but no matter how much he wants to return to those happy days, there‚Äôs no going back ‚Äì he'll never be able to see his loved ones again. This movie‚Äôs depiction of Tanjiro‚Äôs family, entangled in memories both happy and sad, but never to be restored, will have your eyes streaming with tears. 5. And Of Course, the Funny Scenes!Another great element that we get to see again are the hilarious moments between Inosuke and Zenitsu! You‚Äôll also find yourself chuckling at Rengoku as he scarfs down his ekiben (bento lunches bought at train stations). Another heads up ‚Äì at first Zenitsu‚Äôs dream sequence will probably just seem funny, but if you pay attention to where it‚Äôs set, that smile might turn into tears‚Ä¶ (This is especially aimed at anyone who‚Äôs already read the manga up to the Mugen Train arc ‚Äì I want you to think long and hard about where he is in that dream!) Spoiler Alert!From here, I‚Äôll be introducing specific details about the movie, so please stop reading if you want to avoid spoilers.‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚Üì‚ÜìAlright! Let‚Äôs keep going with more highlights, including actual scenes from the movie! 6. An Unprecedented Battle of IntellectTanjiro‚Äôs new foe, and the demon controlling the Mugen Train is Enmu, Lower Rank One in the Twelve Kizuki. Before the events of the movie, Muzan himself took a liking to Enmu and gifted him with Muzan‚Äôs blood. Having gained power with this infusion, Enmu decides to enlist the help of humans ‚Äì or rather, use them as a means for his plan. Thus, the lives of Tanjiro, Zenitsu, Inosuke, Nezuko, and their mission companion, Rengoku, as well as the train‚Äôs many regular passengers, are Enmu‚Äôs next targets. His gentle and calm manner of speaking and friendly smile prove to make him an even more sinister character. Carrying out his plan with meticulous care, Enmu attempts to put Tanjiro and the other humans to sleep forever through his Blood Demon Art, a style of attack that they‚Äôve never faced before. How will Tanjiro and his fellow Demon Slayers wake themselves up from Enmu‚Äôs eternal dreams? 7. The Sudden Appearance of Upper Rank Three, AkazaThe last part of the movie takes a huge turn with the sudden appearance of Akaza (Upper Rank Three) and his fierce battle against Rengoku. Just before dawn, Tanjiro and the others finally get the chance to breathe a sigh of relief, having defeated Enmu and checked that the passengers are safe. But this only lasts for a moment, with the Demon Slayers gathered facing the dreaded Upper Rank Three for the first time. The sudden roaring sound signals the appearance of something... but then dies down, leaving an eerie silence. Then, a pair of eyes glisten in the darkness. This frightening sense of anticipation crosses the screen to weigh down on you, causing you to instinctively clench your fists in suspense‚Ä¶Despite Akaza being a favorite among  KnY‚Äôs many demons, we didn‚Äôt get any information on his voice actor, or even still images until the movie‚Äôs official release. As a result, fans speculated that the movie might only cover Enmu‚Äôs arc and stop before showing Akaza, or that the anime series would continue with his story. However, the movie‚Äôs premiere date came and the cat was finally let out of the bag. We now know that Akaza‚Äôs voice actor is Akira Ishida, famous for roles like Kaworu Nagisa in  Neon Genesis Evangelion! This casting was a huge yet welcome surprise for fans. If you‚Äôre watching the movie with Japanese audio, be sure to soak up every moment of Akaza‚Äôs malevolence, madness and despair through Ishida‚Äôs formidable voice acting!One more highlight is the overwhelming energy of Rengoku and Akaza in their battle scenes, yet another part where you can‚Äôt afford to blink. If IMAX screenings are available near you, take advantage of them and experience the fight‚Äôs sheer power at full volume. It goes without saying that you can still experience plenty at normal theaters, but I urge you to go and feel the huge impact behind each and every hit at IMAX volume levels! The depiction of the snowflake patterns in Akaza‚Äôs Technique Deployment ability is also a highlight. In the original manga‚Äôs 18th volume, we learn about Akaza‚Äôs past. Despite being a ruthless demon with numerous victims, the sorrows of his life as a human capture the pity of readers. Personally, he‚Äôs one of my favorite characters. After watching the movie, I also recommend going right to the rest of the manga to continue the story! 8. Tears of FrustrationAt the end of the battle, Tanjiro and his companions are overwhelmed by the realization that they are still too weak, no matter how much work they put in or how hard they train. Sneering down with their seemingly infinite power are the demons. Haunted by the thought that they couldn‚Äôt do anything, that they had to be protected by others, the young humans have faced frustration, sadness, and uncontrollable tears. For the sake of their slain family members and beloved people they still had to protect, they‚Äôve trained over and over, fought to survive the Final Selection, narrowly escaped death every night, and made huge progress. Yet their power was still nowhere near enough. And now, the man they had followed has fallen victim to their enemies. No matter how many times you watch the movie, this realization will tear your heart to shreds. In the face of such a tragedy, Inosuke offers some words that are deeply touching. His upbringing among wild boars may have given him less experience with other people, but we can see that he‚Äôs grown yet again as a human.  9. Rengoku‚Äôs Explosive Battle Through LifeFans who have already read the manga will know what I‚Äôm talking about. In any case, I won‚Äôt elaborate too much, but I urge you to burn his battles and his way of life into your mind ‚Äì why he risks his life in battle, why he tries to protect humans. His crystal-clear beliefs and promises will also give you an insight into the loneliness he must bear. Protect the weak. Respect one‚Äôs duty and values. In what light will you see these warriors and hear their words as they fight to protect others? If you have the chance, please find out on the big screen. Finally, let me leave you with these words: ‚ÄúKeep your heart burning!‚Äù (And don‚Äôt forget a handkerchief!)This is a Tokyo Otaku Mode original article with text and illustrations by HER.--Need some more quality time with the KnY crew? Bring them home with these adorable figures!
